story:
My name is Sophia, I'm 19 and I am currently living in Colorado. I have recently gathered together a small collection of my poems  that I hope to publish and sell to the public. I have designed my own cover and am very interested in using a small letterpress to imprint it onto the front of my books. However I don't have the funds  to rent/buy a letterpress to make that possible. I will also need to buy paper and ink to make several physical copies.

Once I purchase the press I don't plan on hogging it all to myself. I am a part of a creative community and I will be offering it to others to use, hopefully creating opportunities for multiple authors and artists to utilize this resource. You will be helping me to publish a book, but also to create a new small press.

I have always been very passionate about writing, and I have received many positive reviews about my poems from people at open mic nights and those that I live with. The idea of being a published author is extremely exciting to me, and I am so close to getting there. I think that if I published these books myself they would be even more valuable to me and hopefully those who receive them.

Another reason I want to publish my poetry, is so that I can share my experiences; most of all my experiences with depression and anxiety, which are two things I have struggled with for most of my life. I want to reach out and lend a hand to anyone out there who is going through a dark time, or has ever been there. Sometimes knowing that you are not alone, and that there is someone out there with a similar story who has made it through, can help one hold onto the few threads of hope they have left. I’m not saying I am the cure, or that I can help everyone, but I want to put myself out there in a way that hopefully makes an impact on someone’s life.

The letterpress I am looking at to buy is a Kelsey Excelsior 5x8 Press: $1250

I am planning on printing 150 copies, the ink and paper will cost approximately: $500

story:
For the last 9 months, I've been working as a struggling freelance writer while I looked for regular employment. I was finally offered a full-time gig and will need some help in getting set up. As this is a work-from-home position for the first three months before I move to Colorado, I have a need for office-y type things and basic living expenses until I start receiving a regular paycheck.

Any funds I receive will go towards office equipment such as a chair and desk, as well as food and basic bill money until I can be self-sufficient. Also, any help is greatly appreciated and will be returned tenfold in karmic retribution.

story:
Leggi in italiano


Over a century ago, in 1913, Grandfather Fernando set off on his travels, without even a passport, but with a great thirst for adventure. He left behind his place of birth, Mantua, crossed  Balkan Europe that was being shaken by the winds of war, stopping for a while in Constantinople (capital city of the Ottoman Empire) . From there, he journeyed on to reach the city of Arabian Nights, the mythical Baghdad.

Heartbroken by his sweetheart’s parents’ refusal to let her marry him (because of his lack of means and social status), he set off on his journey, filled with a determination to show the world what he was made of. This led Grandfather Fernando to the role of War Correspondent, or ‘Travelling Editor’ as they called them in those days, but without any credentials in the form of ‘papers or qualifications’ that he didn’t possess.

Aware of his own ignorance, he decided to gain an education by signing up to the largest of all universities, the only one that might welcome him without qualifications: the University of Life,  the mother of gypsies and travellers, who welcomed him with open arms amongst her many, desperate sons.

He set out on the road, like so many Italians then and like so many people from every part of the world even today, to search for a better life for himself and a better story to tell his children.

Turning his face to the rising sun, his soul buoyed up by dreams, he tackled the road, white and dusty in the ice of a Lombardy February morning. And there he learnt many things, as the road revealed so many of life’s secrets. While there, he learnt obscure, guttural languages, new customs and unknown religions.  The road showed him things that he had never seen before.

I found out how he lived, recorded in his diaries, in his letters and in various documents, in an old trunk. Piece by piece, I was able to reconstruct a clear account of hope and dreams, of adventures and of his love for his family and homeland.


Along with this intriguing story, however, Grandfather Fernando also left behind him a number of mysteries, so I have decided that the only way to find out the answers is to follow the trail that he left.

Probably, after all this time, so many places have changed, the names written on the pages of the diary have faded and the facts written down seem to be a stretch of the imagination. But I want to tell his story and find my answers!

And I would like to do it having seen what he saw and felt what he felt!

However, being currently out of work, I really do feel like he did when he set out. When will I ever have another moment like this? Surely now is the right time to leave.

The departure

I mentioned what I wanted to do to my wife, Lucia, who (unpredictably) replied: “Go now! If not now, when...?”

I was somewhat disorientated: What to do? How to organize it? Where to go? Who to contact?

One way or another, however, I will be leaving on the 15th March 2015.

I will be travelling from Mantua, following the same road described by Grandfather, sadly having to stop in Constantinople (Istanbul) because of the current situation in the Middle East.

Travelling alongside me will be Fabrizio Annibali, a professional photographer, who has the ability to make pictures talk and to tell incredible stories with the images he snaps around the world. What better travelling companion for an adventure like this?

The Project

The idea behind this project is to create a book in which you can enjoy a mixture of the pages of Grandfather Fernando, the first-hand experiences of the era and our pursuit, 100 years later. Not a travel guide like so many others, but a mix of notes, quotes and photos of the past and present: a sort of scrap book, a travel album, created on our travels.

It will function as a time machine to join two worlds, two eras, two men, or maybe more. It will make things that appeared very diverse actually seem more similar than you would have thought possible, and it will bear testament to the fact that people everywhere are always the same: priceless and unique!

There have been numerous changes in communication, travelling and writing, but even after 100 years the dreams, the hopes and the feelings of these people are still the same.

However, to make this dream come true, I need your help. I need to raise some money for the journey and to find an old car capable of taking me to Istanbul, so that I can create, edit and publish the book on my return.

How to follow the journey

If you are unable to contribute financially - and no-one understands that better than me at this moment - it doesn’t mean you can’t help. I would really appreciate it if you could share this campaign on Facebook or Twitter or send it to any of your contacts who might be interested in the project. For us, it will be very important just to know that you are there for us and that you are joining in the journey, following our adventure as we trace the footsteps of Grandfather Fernando.

You can follow our journey directly on Twitter and on Facebook; we will also be keeping a diary of this journey, which you can read on our website StoryCity. We will be telling the story as if we were sat around a camp fire with all our friends and supporters.

Last but not least, we also need help finding friendly, cheap places to sleep and eat and also (why not?) any suggestions on beautiful things to discover along the way. Helpful travel advice is also very welcome!

I still have many doubts that I will be sharing with you during this adventure. Maybe you can help me find the answers.

And afterwards?

We will eventually arrive at Istanbul (Constantinople) but the story carries on: Grandfather Fernando journeyed on to Syria and then travelled on foot across the deserts between Damascus and Aleppo. Then, yet further, to Baghdad from where he returned to join up as a volunteer in the Great War.

If you enjoy our travels to Istanbul, we will also complete the second part of the journey from Constantinople to Baghdad and then we will follow Grandfather into the trenches of the First World War and beyond!


Italiano


Circa 100 anni fa mio nonno Fernando partì, senza neanche il passaporto, per un lungo viaggio che lo portò da Mantova fino a Baghdad. Il suo sogno era di fare il giornalista, o "redattore viaggiante" come si diceva all'epoca, ma senza "carte o titoli" tutte le porte rimanevano chiuse.

“Sapendo di esser troppo ignorante per farsi leggere decise di iscriversi alla più grande delle Università, la sola che potesse accoglierlo senza esami: la Strada, la madre degli zingari, ed essa gli aprì le braccia accettandolo fra i suoi numerosi disperati figli.”

Con il un cuore spezzato (la ragazza che amava andò in sposa ad un ufficiale più ricco e maturo) e una fortissima determinazione...

“Camminando di faccia al sole che si levava, gonfio l'animo ventenne di sogni, affrontò la grande scuola, la strada, bianca e polverosa nel gelo d'un febbraio lombardo.

Ed essa gli insegnò tante e tante cose, gli svelò mille segreti della vita, di cui essa è la grande arteria attraverso cui si riversa pazzamente il flusso della gente che vive l'inutile periodo dell'esistenza.

Da essa apprese lingue astruse dalla pronuncia dura, costumi nuovi e religioni ignorate, vide per essa cose mai viste.”

Il suo è un racconto carico di speranza e di sogni, di avventure e di amore per la famiglia e per la propria patria, che filtrano attraverso i suoi diari, le sue lettere e i documenti che ho ritrovato nel suo vecchio baule.

Insieme a una meravigliosa e affascinante storia però ha lasciato dietro sé anche moltissimi misteri. Così ho deciso che l’unico modo per trovare le risposte era di partire e di seguire le tracce che mi ha lasciato. E’ probabile che dopo tutto questo tempo si siano perse nelle pieghe del tempo, ma io questa storia devo raccontarla e trovare le mie risposte! E vorrei farlo avendo visto quello che ha visto lui e provato quello che ha provato lui. Essendo senza lavoro mi sento proprio come lui quando è partito! Quando mai mi capiterà ancora un momento come questo? E' il momento giusto di partire.



Qualcosa su di noi

Poiché da gennaio sono ufficialmente senza un lavoro propriamente detto, potete ben immaginare la mia sorpresa quando parlando di questa idea balzana con mia moglie mi ha detto: “parti”. Ero quasi disorientato. Cosa dovevo fare? organizzare? andare? Sia come sia si parte il 15 di marzo da Mantova ripercorrendo la stessa strada descritta nei suoi i racconti fermandomi però -purtroppo- a Costantinopoli (Istanbul), a causa dell’attuale situazione in medio oriente.

Insieme a me viaggerà Fabrizio Annibali, un bravissimo fotografo italiano, che documenterà l’avventura.

Di cosa ho bisogno

Vorrei raccontare queste avventure “on the road” in un libro in cui si intrecciano il racconto di nonno Fernando, gli avvenimenti storici dell'epoca, e il nostro inseguimento, cento anni dopo. Non vorrei che fosse un libro come tutti gli altri, ma un libro ricco di immagini bellissime, una sorta di scrap book, un album di viaggio, costruito per strada.

Questo libro vorrebbe essere l’incontro tra due mondi, tra due periodi storici che diventano sempre più diversi, ma che testimoniano come le persone sono sempre le stesse. Cambia il modo di comunicare, di viaggiare, di scrivere, ma dopo cento anni i sogni, le speranze e i sentimenti delle persone si ritrovano ancora immutati.


Per fare tutto questo, per realizzare questo sogno ho bisogno del tuo aiuto. Ho bisogno di raccogliere i fondi necessari per il viaggio, inclusa una vecchia macchina in grado di portarmi fino a Istanbul, e per realizzare e pubblicare il libro.

Altri modi in cui puoi aiutare

Se pensi di non poter dare un contributo economico -chi meglio di me può capirti?- per noi sarà molto importante anche solo sapere che ci sei e che stai partecipando al racconto. Puoi seguire il viaggio “on-the-road” in diretta su Twitter e su Facebook, mentre terremo il diario di viaggio sul sito web di StoryCity, ve lo racconteremo come se fossimo intorno ad un fuoco.

Apprezzeremo moltissimo se vorrai invitare anche i tuoi amici a condividere questo progetto.

Inoltre abbiamo bisogno di aiuto per trovare posti accoglienti ed economici dove dormire e mangiare e -perché no?- anche per scoprire le cose belle da vedere lungo la strada. E poiché ho ancora molti nodi da sciogliere di tanto in tanto li condividerò con voi che mi leggete e, se lo vorrai, potrai aiutarmi da casa a trovare le risposte.

E dopo?

Noi arriveremo fino a Istanbul (Costantinopoli) ma poi la storia prosegue, Fernando è ripartito per la Siria e si è fatto un bel pezzo di strada a piedi in zone desertiche tra Damasco e Aleppo e poi ancora fino a Baghdad, da cui è tornato per partecipare come volontario alla prima grande guerra.

Se la storia fino a Istanbul vi sarà piaciuta vedremo di realizzare la seconda parte e vi racconteremo la prima guerra mondiale dalle trincee con le sue parole.

Leggi in italianoOver a century ago, in 1913, Grandfather Fernando set off on his travels, without even a passport, but with a great thirst for adventure. He left behind his place of birth, Mantua, crossed  Balkan Europe that was being shaken by the winds of war, stopping for a while in Constantinople (capital city of the Ottoman Empire) . From there, he journeyed on to reach the city of Arabian Nights, the mythical Baghdad.Heartbroken by his sweetheart’s parents’ refusal to let her marry him (because of his lack of means and social status), he set off on his journey, filled with a determination to show the world what he was made of. This led Grandfather Fernando to the role of War Correspondent, or ‘Travelling Editor’ as they called them in those days, but without any credentials in the form of ‘papers or qualifications’ that he didn’t possess.Aware of his own ignorance, he decided to gain an education by signing up to the largest of all universities, the only one that might welcome him without qualifications: the University of Life,  the mother of gypsies and travellers, who welcomed him with open arms amongst her many, desperate sons.He set out on the road, like so many Italians then and like so many people from every part of the world even today, to search for a better life for himself and a better story to tell his children. Turning his face to the rising sun, his soul buoyed up by dreams, he tackled the road, white and dusty in the ice of a Lombardy February morning. And there he learnt many things, as the road revealed so many of life’s secrets. While there, he learnt obscure, guttural languages, new customs and unknown religions.  The road showed him things that he had never seen before.I found out how he lived, recorded in his diaries, in his letters and in various documents, in an old trunk. Piece by piece, I was able to reconstruct a clear account of hope and dreams, of adventures and of his love for his family and homeland.Along with this intriguing story, however, Grandfather Fernando also left behind him a number of mysteries, so I have decided that the only way to find out the answers is to follow the trail that he left.Probably, after all this time, so many places have changed, the names written on the pages of the diary have faded and the facts written down seem to be a stretch of the imagination. But I want to tell his story and find my answers!And I would like to do it having seen what he saw and felt what he felt!However, being currently out of work, I really do feel like he did when he set out. When will I ever have another moment like this? Surely now is the right time to leave.The departureI mentioned what I wanted to do to my wife, Lucia, who (unpredictably) replied: “Go now! If not now, when...?”I was somewhat disorientated: What to do? How to organize it? Where to go? Who to contact?One way or another, however, I will be leaving on the 15th March 2015.I will be travelling from Mantua, following the same road described by Grandfather, sadly having to stop in Constantinople (Istanbul) because of the current situation in the Middle East.Travelling alongside me will be Fabrizio Annibali, a professional photographer, who has the ability to make pictures talk and to tell incredible stories with the images he snaps around the world. What better travelling companion for an adventure like this?The ProjectThe idea behind this project is to create a book in which you can enjoy a mixture of the pages of Grandfather Fernando, the first-hand experiences of the era and our pursuit, 100 years later. Not a travel guide like so many others, but a mix of notes, quotes and photos of the past and present: a sort of scrap book, a travel album, created on our travels.It will function as a time machine to join two worlds, two eras, two men, or maybe more. It will make things that appeared very diverse actually seem more similar than you would have thought possible, and it will bear testament to the fact that people everywhere are always the same: priceless and unique!There have been numerous changes in communication, travelling and writing, but even after 100 years the dreams, the hopes and the feelings of these people are still the same.However, to make this dream come true, I need your help. I need to raise some money for the journey and to find an old car capable of taking me to Istanbul, so that I can create, edit and publish the book on my return.How to follow the journeyIf you are unable to contribute financially - and no-one understands that better than me at this moment - it doesn’t mean you can’t help. I would really appreciate it if you could share this campaign on Facebook or Twitter or send it to any of your contacts who might be interested in the project. For us, it will be very important just to know that you are there for us and that you are joining in the journey, following our adventure as we trace the footsteps of Grandfather Fernando.You can follow our journey directly on Twitter and on Facebook; we will also be keeping a diary of this journey, which you can read on our website StoryCity. We will be telling the story as if we were sat around a camp fire with all our friends and supporters.Last but not least, we also need help finding friendly, cheap places to sleep and eat and also (why not?) any suggestions on beautiful things to discover along the way. Helpful travel advice is also very welcome!I still have many doubts that I will be sharing with you during this adventure. Maybe you can help me find the answers.And afterwards?We will eventually  arrive at Istanbul (Constantinople) but the story carries on: Grandfather Fernando journeyed on to Syria and then travelled on foot across the deserts between Damascus and Aleppo. Then, yet further, to Baghdad from where he returned to join up as a volunteer in the Great War.If you enjoy our travels to Istanbul, we will also complete the second part of the journey from Constantinople to Baghdad and then we will follow Grandfather into the trenches of the First World War and beyond!ItalianoCirca 100 anni fa mio nonno Fernando partì, senza neanche il passaporto, per un lungo viaggio che lo portò da Mantova fino a Baghdad. story:
One young woman's decade long tale of adventure, lessons in love and journey to authenticity as she travels the world independently. Follow Carmella as she explores the globe with reckless abandon. An unabashedly raw and charmingly genuine account of her real life experience taken directly from her travel diaries.

Nearly a decade ago, I left life as I knew it (rat race drone selling my soul to Corporate America) and took a risk. A big one. And this is my story of how it has worked out for me. Over the last ten years, I wrote what became a well read (to my surprise) travel blog. "Wandering around the world to see what I can find. Aimlessly from place to place with no real plan in mind. I have no idea what I am doing or where I am going. Every time I plan, things change. So... no more plan." 


One needs something to believe in, something for which one can have whole-hearted enthusiasm. One needs to feel that one's life has meaning, that one is needed in this world. - Hannah Senesh


Volume one covers 2002 to 2003 travel in Switzerland, Greece, Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, Netherlands, England, Wales, Ireland, Scotland, France, Spain, Italy, Australia, and New Zealand.

The Impact

For the first few years, I really had a hard time believing anyone was actually reading it other than my mom and maybe my sister. But now, I have had years of thank you letters confirming that I had many more follows than I could have imagined. Many have encouraged me to publish into a book so that those who do not have internet access can be inspired by the story. In the past year, I have been approached if I would allow my writing to be translated into Turkish, Arabic, and Korean. Last month, while travelling in Jordan I unexpectedly met one of my loyal readers. So here it is. I will publish it if you will help me. I already know I have had amazing support and don't doubt that for a second. How else does a crazy Canadian girl run around the world alone unscathed? If it is time for this book to be published, then together we can make it happen.


We rely upon the poets, the philosophers, and the playwrights to articulate what most of us can only feel, in joy and sorrow. They illuminate the thoughts for which we only grope; they give us the strength and balm we cannot find in ourselves. Whenever I feel my courage wavering I rush to them. They will give me the wisdom of acceptance, the will and resilience to push on. - Helen Hayes



What We Need & What You Get

I have consulted with several publishers, copy editors, and designers. I want it to be affordable yet still professional and something to be proud of. Now we are just waiting on the funds.  If the funds are not raised, I will at the very least publish an eBook. If it is a resounding success, then I will be delivering these books around the world to help inspire others to follow their dreams. Check out the perks and see how you can touch the lives of underprivledged youth or contribute to libraries around the world by your donation. I remember, you said I could do it...now let's see if you're right.


Our true wealth is the good we do in this world. None of us has faith unless we desire for our neighbors what we desire for ourselves.- Mohammed

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit counts...and I am so grateful for all the support. If you believe in this project, then please post this to your Facebook, Twitter, and webpages. Email your friends and family if you think they may be interested in a story about believing in yourself, against all odds.

 

There is no such thing as a "self-made" man. We are made up of thousands of others. Everyone who has ever done a kind deed for us, or spoken one word of encouragement to us, has entered into the make-up of our character and of our thoughts, as well as our success. - George Matthew Adams

story:
My Story

This could be the story of a woman with a serious drawing impediment but, it's not (quite).
It's the story of a recent survivor of stage IV colon cancer...my story.  I went through a long and bumpy road to get here but, I made it to the other side and am eagerly greeting my second lease on life~

There are so many things I've learned along the way which have made me all the stronger and wiser but, I wish someone had handed me a guide on day 1 and saved me the trouble of learning some things the hard way.

This book is just that, an insider guide for someone newly diagnosed with cancer and for those who love them and want to help but, don't know where the !&%# to start.

You'll laugh, you'll cry, then you'll laugh while you're crying and best of all my short attention span theater fans...you'll be able to read it all in a day (about 80 pages). Look for excerpts on the facebook fan page...

Look, see there on the right...?  Make a $30 contribution and get your advanced/autographed copy of the book before it launches on Amazon or $100 and get a personal thank you and your name printed in the book!

The Impact

According to the American Cancer Society, over 7 million people in the world die of cancer every year.  I think that's just f'd up and needs to change, today...

By contributing to this campaign you will be helping to give people an alternative to an otherwise grave and dramatic view of cancer and offering them an insightful way of dealing with it.

Also, once its published, a portion of all sales will go to established non-profit organizations that support those struggling with the costs of cancer treatment and you'll be able to follow that progress with quarterly updates on our website: www.theccardandme.com.


What We Need & What You Get

Funding for the publishing and marketing of the book, that's what we need pure and simple.  After researching further I found that Amazon/Createspace had the best deal and cut the cost of publishing in half from my original estimate.  They were really helpful and broke it down in a way that was easy for me and my chemo brain to soak in: $1,180 to edit/format/publish the book, $69 to make it available on Kindle then $600 to market it (press releases to over 1,000 TV/radio/magazines with that interest) with an estimate of 10 weeks from the time we start the editing process on February 17th, 2012 to it being on Amazon's virtual shelf (and autographed copies are in the hands of contributors just prior).

I could submit it to publishers and wait months on end for one to see its merit and take action but, I think of all those diagnosed with cancer every day and how their heads are reeling and I just don't want to wait for this to be in their hands.

By contributing anywhere between $30 and $1,000 or more, you'll become a Card Carrying Member with an autographed copy of the book and the satisfaction of being part of a movement to relegate this little punk-ass disease to the lower ranks and recesses of all our minds and lives.


What If We Surpass the Goal?

It means we'll be able to extend the reach of the book by having it available in bookstores,  through further marketing and make it available in several other languages throughout the world.  C'est Magnifique!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word by liking The C Card and Me page on facebook, following us on twitter, telling others to and to contribute to the campaign.  For every effort you make, THANK YOU!

story:
My screams went out, "Please someone help me!  Someone Help Me!  Please stop!  SOMEONE please save me!"  No one came to rescue me because the screams were in my head.  Similar screams were yelled out into the darkness twenty years later on a very lonely desperate road.  No mortal being was there to rescue me then either.  The darkest moments in our lives are generally faced alone; no one can save us in those moments but God and ourselves. But God does place people in our lives to support us on our journey through the dark times.  I share my story in this book to do just that---help people on their own personal journeys of darkness.  I survived rape, a consequential downward spiral from that, and the inability to accept my Dad's tragic and sudden death (which ultimately lead me to an attempted suicide).  I was able to step out of my darkness because of five elements in my life.  These elements woven together allowed me to survive the nightmares and turn them into something good.  Through my own story, I hope to tell others how to weave these five elements into their lives to face the demons in their own nightmares, conquer them, and thrive emotionally, spiritually, and physically in spite of them.


What I Need 

No one came to my rescue during my dark times: however I am asking for your help today during a happier time.  My book will be out in print in September; however, I need your help to raise the additional funds to get these books into hands of the people who need it.  Your funds will go towards editing, cover design, marketing costs in obtaining a publisher, and printing of my book. I have high hopes that we can raise more than the $5,000 so that I am able to kick off a motivational speaking tour, then I can really start to touch lives in a personal way.


The Impact

By financially supporting my book, you may be helping others in their nightmares.  You may be helping the poor college student who is lying on the floor crying from the pain and shame they feel.  Or you may be helping the person at the end of a dark road contemplating ending it all to see another way out.  You may be helping any one of a thousand people who are struggling with nightmares in their lives.  If my book can reach even one person and help them carry their heavy load of darkness and find the light, then you, too, will have helped that person.  This world can use more people helping each other.  I plan to try in every way I can to do just that.  Maybe together, we can make a difference in someone's life, maybe even someone you love.



Thank You


Sidenote:

If you want to donate to this project but aren't able to do so with a Credit Card or Paypal.  Email me at shandyloberg@hotmail.com and I will get you an address so that you may send a check.

story:
This magazine offers  a comprehensive view of contemporary Latin American and  Caribbean societies by showcasing what is working within the region and discussing  the challenges and shortcomings. 

It offers a space for everyday people from the region to tell the world about them, their community, their culture, their dreams, challenges and setback. 

The simple story is that it is designed to be a living encyclopedia of contemporary Latin American and Caribbean communities in the region as well as within the diaspora.

Your financial contribution is helping in 3 fundamental ways:

1) Allowing us to set the cover price at an affordable rate ($9.97 per issue) 

2) Helping create a centralized collective platform about Latin American and Caribbean societies

2)Making it accessible to a wider public.
