story:
Hi. My name is Patrick Potter, and I am coming to you with a very unusual fundraiser. When this is over, you will understand that there is a PURPOSE to all of this, the end result of which will be A MULTIMEDIA PROJECT EVENT that will utilize video, music, prose, satirical cartoons and illustrations to capture the torment that I have been put through by the banking system, mortgage holders, employees thereof and more while trying to save my childhood home from what is, for all intent and purposes, an illegal foreclosure.

This fundraiser is called THE PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN, which is designed to raise money to save my home, located here in Largo, Florida. Obviously a project very near and dear to my heart.

TO GIVE YOU SOME BACKGROUND ON HOW ALL THIS CAME TO BE:

I grew up in this home, which my mother bought as it was built in 1973. We are the only family that has ever lived in the home. My mother was a widow, my dad having died when I was four. After dad died, my grandma - mom's mom - moved in to help mom take care of me so that mom could work. At the time we moved into the house, I was ten years old.

I was 19 when I moved out to marry my first wife. I began working for a comic book store chain in October 1982. I bought the Largo, Florida store on December 1st, 1992, and have continued to run my comic book store ever since, through good times and bad. For four years, I was also a substitute teacher, from 2002 - 2006.

Grandma lived with mom in the home after I grew up and moved out. She passed away in the home at age 93 on September 12, 2000. Mom developed lung disease in 2001. By 2003, she was in need of assistance. Mom's lung disease became terminal in 2006. She passed away at home at age 77 on February 6, 2007. I was caregiver to them both in their final years.

I was dismissed by the Pinellas County School Board from my substitute teaching position in June 2007 for failing to work as a sub during my mother's final few months, from 2006-2007. After Mom passed, I had to deal with her estate, and I was very emotional. I planned to return to subbing in August of 2007, but the school board refused to hold my position.

I moved into the home shortly after mom passed away, in April 2007. The house went through the probate process as part of her estate. By summer of 2007, the house was then put into my name. I had picked up making the mortgage payments when mom died, and continued straight through UNTIL, in May of 2009, I received a letter from the bank -- which was Wachovia at the time -- stating that my mortgage had gone from the $525.00 a month payment to $983.00 due to an escrow shortage. I immediately called the bank, who informed me that the escrow shortage was related to either property taxes or homeowner's insurance.

I then began to pursue a plan to refinance the mortgage, but Wachovia's representative stated that they would not allow me to do that, but that I had to do a Loan Modification instead. I didn't know what that was. They told me to write a hardship letter, and told me what to say IN the hardship letter, and to call them back the next day. Meanwhile, they would mail out a Loan Modification package to me. After that call, I spoke to an attorney friend who said yes, Loan Modifications are the thing to do these days. Remember, this was summer of 2009. My accountant said he was doing five of them at the time for clients. This made me feel more secure about moving forward, but I still felt that a refi would have been simpler and safer to do.

But Wachovia was the bank, and they held all the cards.

When we began the Loan Modification process, I was told that they would be canceling my old account number and assigning my mortgage a NEW account number. When I asked how I would make payments, they said that until the Loan Modification process was complete, I would have no payments. Once it was complete, I would receive a coupon booklet, and have 30 days to make the payments. I would then have to make the payments on time, each month, or would be dropped from the program.

I asked if I would be in default. They said no, I would not be in default throughout this process. I asked what happened to the payments I wasn't making. They said all payments, taxes and insurance would be put "on the back end". I asked if there were any penalties, and again, they replied in the negative. There were no fees, fines or penalties because I was doing a Loan Modification.

Again, they were the lender. They held all the cards. So I had to believe them, didn't I?

I followed through, receiving and returning documents with my accountant's assistance. This process went on for months. Just as I was wondering when the Loan Modification would be approved, in January 2010, I was contacted by Wells Fargo, who had taken over Wachovia. They said that they were canceling my Loan Modification BUT they were putting me in the *new and improved* President's Loan Modification Plan. They made it sound like a sure bet, no problem making it go through, and once again, we had to resubmit all-new forms.

Again, I asked them about making payments, and they reiterated: I would have no payments during the Loan Modification process. Likewise, I would not be in default, with all payments, taxes and insurance would be put "on the back end". There would be no fees, fines or penalties because I was doing a Loan Modification.

Now it was Wells Fargo holding all the cards, but again, shouldn't I trust them? After all, if all they want is for me to be a current mortgage holder, then this process was the way to go, wasn't it?

My accountant assured me, "They have enough houses in foreclosure, Pat. They don't want your home."

With his help, I once again threw myself into the process of the Loan Modification machine.

Around this time, my friend the attorney, who specializes in family law, said, "Have Wells Fargo fax me a letter stating the terms they've told you. You should have all that in writing."

So I called the guy I'd spoken to, who said that he "couldn't fax anything out of the office".

I said, "What are you talking about, you can't fax? Then e-mail him a letter."

The guy replied, "Oh no, we can't e-mail out of these offices either."

I told the attorney what the Wells Fargo rep said, and he replied, "Call him back and have him contact the mortgage department and make SURE they don't put you in foreclosure!"

"But," I said, "I'm not even in default!" The attorney was adamant, so I did as instructed.

The Wells Fargo rep replied, "Oh no, we can't contact that department, we don't have the ability to contact any department outside our own!"

"What are you talking about, aren't you ALL Wells Fargo?" He said yes, but "the system" wasn't set up to allow them to speak to the other departments.

Now, you're all saying what everyone else does at this point. Wasn't I suspicious? Didn't this send up red flags? Sure it did! But Wells Fargo was the new lender, and now it was they who held all the cards! What was I supposed to do, call them all liars?

This process went on and on and on -- throughout the entire year of 2010, and through 2011 until September of that year. Throughout that entire time, we would be told that the paperwork had expired, "grown stale", and told to resubmit, resubmit, resubmit some more, which we did ad nauseum. We did everything we were told to do. What else were we SUPPOSED to do?

From January 2010 until September 2011, I was traded off from one Home Preservation "Specialist" to another, each one coming across like nothing more than a glorified telemarketer. In September 2011, the third of these "specialists" sent me a letter, denying my Loan Modification -- after over TWO years of being jerked around, claiming that my Profit and Loss statement (for my comic store) was insufficient.

By the 28th of September, Wells Fargo had filed a foreclosure against me, and mailed me the paperwork so that it arrived ON my birthday, October 1st, 2011. I spent the day crying.

With the help of my attorney friend, I filed a counter against their foreclosure, but was forced to hire an attorney in the beginning of 2012 -- Stamatakis + Thalji + Bonanno -- in Tampa, recommended to my accountant, who passed that information along to me. I gave them a retainer, and they began the process of filing motions to dismiss, among other motions. This point-counterpoint went back and forth without anyone gaining ground for two years. Every so often, we'd hear from them that motions were being filed, but that everything was the same. No change.

Here's where things take a BAD TURN, and it all started with -- a wedding!

By this point in my life, 2011-2014, I had a girlfriend -- Ashley -- whom I met in the latter days near the end of my first marriage when she began helping out at the comic shop, taking over for the fellow who was moving away, while I was busy taking care of Mom before she died. After my first wife and I separated again in 2007, Ashley and I became more and more involved, first as friends before becoming near inseparable companions. We have almost everything in common, and our differences in interests are negligible and endearing. My divorce of my first marriage was final December 1st, 2011. Ashley and I became engaged on Christmas Day 2012, almost 13 months later.

We envisioned growing older in that house -- she's younger than I am, and would like children of her own -- and spoke of having a family of our own there in my childhood home. I thought of how happy that would have made Mom and Grandma, to bring the joy of a full-on family back to the house. My children are all grown, and I really like the idea of having a second chance to be a dad again. When my first wife and I were married -- very young -- I admit with deep regret that I was far more self-centered and self-absorbed than I am now. I was a good dad, mind you -- never went out with the boys, or played golf or sports, nor was I abusive in any way -- but I was *a real couch potato*, coming in after work to watch my TV shows, eat dinner, and do my own thing. I regret not spending more time with my kids, other than to help them with homework and read to them sometimes before bedtime. I would love to have a second chance to be a better dad. I can't make up the lost time to my adult children -- I wish I could, because I love them with all my heart -- but I know I'm a better man today than I was when I was younger.

Ashley has gone back to college to become an RN, and is currently taking courses. As of December 2014, she has about 18 months remaining before she will have her Associates in Science degree and her RN license.

Of course, as couples do, Ashley and I began tossing wedding dates back and forth when we might like to get married. The one date which came up was February 22nd, because that was my Grandma's birthday. It wasn't until I learned that my Dad's parents were also married on February 22nd that I really got that date stuck in my head. It seemed so perfect, to honor my parents and grandparents. I left it up to Ashley, however, because I'd already been married before, and had my big day. She had ideas how we'd proceed with a big ceremony, but felt that we could renew our vows in a big ceremony someday later, when so many things had been sorted out -- not the least of which was the house -- but that we could have a civil ceremony on February 22nd of 2014 because the day fell on a Saturday. It won't fall on a Saturday for six more years, and we didn't want to wait six years for that date to be our wedding anniversary.

The entire thing came together in three days, from the day we just spontaneously decided to have our wedding to the date of the wedding. BUT before we did anything, we called the attorneys for the foreclosure defense, because we didn't want ANYTHING to upset the process. The attorney replied, "All this will mean is, when we get into the Loan Modification phase, Ashley will need to provide some proof of income! Otherwise, your getting married won't change a thing!"

WRONG.

We married as we'd hurriedly planned on February 22nd, filing our license with the Clerk of the Court for Pinellas County, Florida a couple of days later. We were so happy and excited!

A couple of months went by. Suddenly, around the end of April, a persistent person kept coming to the house in the mornings, knocking loudly, then leaving and driving away. Well, we're at the comic book store often working late doing paperwork, because that's when it's quiet and Ashley has college classes, as I mentioned earlier. So we're not dressed early in the morning. This went on until the beginning of May, when the person hid his car down the road, and then hid in the neighbor's bushes. Ashley was walking to the car around noon, so we could head to the store. I was just inside the door. The man jumped out, ran across the yard, and served Ashley a set of the foreclosure papers. He began interrogating her, asking her who she was, what business she had at the house and so forth. She had no idea at that moment who he was or what the papers were, so she refused to answer. He ran away as I came out, jumping into his car to speed off.

We were then notified in June 2014 that a hearing had been scheduled for August to set a sale date for the house, to force the foreclosure process through to the ultimate conclusion.

The attorney told us that we could do one of two things: file for a new Loan Modification, which he could do for $500.00, or file for Bankruptcy Chapter 13 for $1,500.00. He said these would stop the foreclosure process and cancel the hearing. We opted for the Loan Modification process. He then said we'd have to do the Bankruptcy instead, but it was a 1 to 5 year process. I *believed* I understood the idea was to discharge debt while improving my debt-to-income ratio, because I knew that term from having done a refinance with my first wife on our old house back in 2004. So I *thought* I understood what was going on now, and hey -- 1 to 5 years? Ashley would be an RN in less than 2 years, so I thought everything would be fine.

WRONG.

I was scouring a lot of avenues trying to come up with the $1,500.00 when I wrote a very good friend of mine for advice. In turn, he said, "I'm going to loan you the money to save your house", and God bless him, I still owe him that money (I haven't forgotten), because he DID come through for me!!

We contacted the attorney to get him the fifteen hundred, who said, "Well, we'll need another $310.00 for filing fees." We had an additional $200.00, so they agreed to take that. All in all, we gave them $1,700.00 for the Bankruptcy which I *thought* I understood, and clearly did NOT. After they were paid, the attorney was able to stop the foreclosure -- don't cheer yet! It was only temporary -- and call off the hearing with days to spare. THEN he dropped the bombshell, we'd meet with a Bankruptcy trustee within a week, and 30 days later -- by the first of October -- we'd have to start paying TWO THOUSAND DOLLARS A MONTH to stay in the house. If we couldn't agree to that, we wouldn't be able to stay in the house!

Why was the monthly amount so high when the Loan Modification -- if it had just gone through originally as planned -- should have reduced the monthly payment from the $983.00 down to around $550.00? Because Wells Fargo has added FEES, PENALTIES, LEGAL FEES, COURT COSTS and MORE to the tune of $50,000.00 on top of the original $82,000.00 mortgage, PLUS tacked on an extra $5,000.00 onto the original mortgage!!

Therefore, to get out from under, if I have to pay the entire sum, I'd have to give them $137,000.00!!

Obviously, we couldn't agree to do $2,000.00 a month, no matter how much I want to stay in my house. I knew I couldn't come up with that kind of money. The trustee then released the bankruptcy, the foreclosure process began again, and a NEW HEARING is set for December 16, 2014. Yes, NEXT WEEK!!!!

Merry Christmas.

We spoke to HUD and looked into the HAMP and HARP programs. After getting a good deal of run around, which left me reduced to tears -- yes, I'm a man, standing in my comic book store, weeping over my boyhood home -- we were told to "approach the lender and start a new Loan Modification".

Again, we approached the attorney: "What about the Loan Modification you mentioned?"

They replied: "We can do that for $500.00, but the hearing will still go through, and a sale date will be set for your house. Or you can do the Loan Modification yourself."

We asked: "Can you take $500.00 from the $1,700.00 we already gave you?"

The answer: "No, that money is already spent."

So we called Wells Fargo ourselves. The woman we spoke to was nice enough. She said to go to a particular page and download the Loan Modification package. She also mailed us one. She said that the hearing against the house could be canceled and the foreclosure stopped before Thanksgiving. Get the paperwork filled out, send it in, and they would call to do a financial interview. I was excited beyond words. Finally, a chance to breathe!

We got the forms, sent them to the accountant, met with him, and he got the forms back to us. This took two weeks of going back and forth -- he also has other clients, I understand that -- and then we called HUD to go over the numbers with THEM before sending the package to Wells Fargo. HUD said it all met the criteria for a successful Loan Modification!

Okay, we called Wells Fargo. They said, "Don't e-mail them, FAX them" and then directed us to go to the branch near us and fax the papers from there. We did this on November 21st, 2014. We then expected the call from Wells Fargo.

WRONG.

There was no call. So WE called. They didn't know who Ashley had spoken to. We said we needed to do the interview. They said someone would call us back. Thanksgiving came and went with no call. Then the first week of December came and went. We called again.

The clock is ticking!

We also called the attorney. "File a motion to stop the hearing, we've started a Loan Modification! They said the hearing would be canceled if we did that ... we're just waiting for the interview call!" So they filed a motion.

But the hearing *wasn't* canceled. So yesterday, we called Wells Fargo AGAIN. Wells Fargo said, "Have your attorney call OUR attorney."

There was still no word by this afternoon.

Today, December 10th, with six days til doomsday, I had the bright idea to speak with the attorney, Chris Young, with whom I've filed for disability due to health issues largely stemming from an automobile accident in 2010, plus serious eyesight issues. To digress a moment: I went blind in my right eye in the summer of 2001, and suffered a retinal detachment in my sighted left eye in the summer of 2011, and almost went blind then.

So today, I thought -- incorrectly -- that the disability attorney might ALSO be able to file a motion to cancel the hearing against my house, as I am diligently working toward that goal while also seeking a new Loan Modification. Perhaps if both attorneys file? He replied no. Apparently, HE was told by the foreclosure attorney that the hearing will not be canceled. Wells Fargo would rather just foreclose on the house.

So much for the statement, "They don't want your house, Pat".

They must think there is buried treasure there.

We called Wells Fargo again, this afternoon, to demand we get this interview process done. They said we have to FAX THE PAPERWORK AGAIN tomorrow. Can you believe it?? The guy said he can't read the typed and printed responses to their own forms!!

SO TOMORROW, with all the paperwork filed -- allegedly -- the Loan Modification process will start again!! BUT the hearing will NOT be canceled. We should go to the Judge next Tuesday, we were told, and tell the Court that we have started a Loan Modification with Wells Fargo!!!

IS THIS A JOKE?

Am I supposed to believe ANYTHING I am told now?

❖ ❖ ❖

WHAT ABOUT THAT FUNDRAISER I STARTED TALKING ABOUT?

So what is this fundraiser about?
Saving the house.

What are the perks?
Well, I own a comic book store. Maybe we can work out a deal on some comics.

As detailed elsewhere ... this Indiegogo format is a whole new world to me, so forgive me if this seems like a repeat:

Or maybe you'd like a copy of one of the sketches I am doing for PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN, the project which will detail *the entire process* that I have endured, from start to -- hopefully -- *blessed* finish, with your help. Donate $50.00 for one sketch or cartoon.

PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN will be a full-out telling of the facts you've read above, with sketches, illustrations, sarcastic "satirical" cartoons, and more. I intend to publish the book through Amazon's CreateSpace and Kindle Direct Publishing features. Those who donate $100.00 will get a free print copy.

The more you contribute, the more you'll get. As I indicated, there will be sketches and cartoons. Four illustrations -- two sketches, two satirical cartoons -- will be printed on card stock and also made available. Donate $250.00 for all four pieces of art and a copy of the book.

Finally, I intend to do three paintings, the designs of which have long been decided on. Each painting is part of a larger theme. The paintings, when done, will be auctioned off on eBay as a set. The theme is PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN, who will be represented in the paintings as a regular person losing his home and family, only to end up homeless. The paintings speak to what is happening, like a plague, in America today.

For those who donate $500.00, you'll get a DVD video of me painting the three paintings, PLUS a free copy of the book, PLUS all four sketches.

– OR –

(This part WASN'T mentioned anywhere else)

If you don't have a lot of money, would you like to DONATE to preserve the good and decent home built by my mother, Rita Potter? Mom worked as a Pediatric Psych Nurse (an RN and CN 4) at Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Florida for over two decades, helping THOUSANDS of young people overcome addictions to drugs as well as deal with psychological disorders, abusive environments, and many distressing issues.

I'm just a comic book store owner. I'm not changing the world. While I would still like to finish my degree in education, survival is the name of the game today. Ashley, on the other hand, has a bright future ahead of her as an RN. Her dream is to work as a Pediatric floor nurse. Helping us save the house is ALSO helping to secure a solid home environment to help Ashley focus on her courses, so that she is not faced with the prospect of being displaced from the home she has come to love so much.

PLEASE HELP US save our home.

It could be as simple as 400,000 people each donating 25 cents per person.

A simple quarter of a dollar could make a difference if enough people can donate to this worthy cause.

What's in it for you?

How many times have the banks, the mortgage companies, and other large organizations spewed their venom and bile onto your lives?

This is YOUR chance to stand up to them! YOU can make a difference by not letting them win!!

Throughout this entire process, I've been told one bald-faced lie after another, and now they want me to swallow the lie that going through the hearing won't result in the foreclosure and sale of my house? That I'll be allowed to complete a Loan Modification?

While I had considered doing this fundraiser many times in the past six months, I did not sit down to write any of this until after Wells Fargo fed us that line of malarkey!!

Yes, tomorrow, we WILL follow through and submit the paperwork. Again.

Yes, tomorrow, we WILL call Wells Fargo YET AGAIN to try to see if the foreclosure process can be stopped.

Yes, tomorrow, we WILL once more attempt to have the hearing against our home stopped.

I DO intend to file a DIRECT request with the Judge. I will go to the Courthouse in Clearwater and file it before I ever set foot in the door of the store. AND I will make sure I have a stamped confirmation that they received it.

Yes, I will go through the motions.

But in the end, I BELIEVE IT'S PEOPLE LIKE YOU who will make the difference!!

WE all represent THE COMMON MAN, and by that I mean "Mankind", meaning ALL GENDERS, as well as sexual orientations, cultures, ethnicity, and religions.

The government consisting of agencies such as HUD and the like, the banks like Wells Fargo and Bank of America, and institutions who say that they will help people like me and you are not in it to help people like you and me, they're in it to help THEMSELVES.

But we can pull together as a people, and not just a nation here in the United States, but as a world of people everywhere. We have to help one another when we can, while we can.

Today, Ashley and I need your help.

Please donate to THE PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN fundraiser today.

Time is of the essence.

Thank you.

Patrick Potter
Largo, Florida

❖ ❖ ❖

Risks and Challenges

I've been asked what risks and challenges I face. In fact, the only challenge is time. There is no risk, unless I don't meet the goal and / or the courts decide NOT to stave off the execution by allowing a sale date to be set for my home.

BUT, if we meet the goal, I believe we can seriously pay off the home! In that case, I have nothing negatively impacting me to prevent me from completing the project, because what banks like Wells Fargo has done is despicable, and I am passionate to want to speak out against the kind of dirty tricks they have used to, for all intents and purposes "steal" people's homes from under them!

I am an extremely multi-talented individual. I am an outstanding writer, an excellent cartoonist and artist, and I am sarcastic and angry enough to follow through and pull off EXACTLY what I am promising you here!

My wife is a wonderful person who can keep the store going if I need to take time away from the shop to stay home and focus on the task, so I know I can meet the deadline I have set for myself.
story_txt: Hi. My name is Patrick Potter, and I am coming to you with a very unusual fundraiser. When this is over, you will understand that there is a PURPOSE to all of this, the end result of which will be A MULTIMEDIA PROJECT EVENT that will utilize video, music, prose, satirical cartoons and illustrations to capture the torment that I have been put through by the banking system, mortgage holders, employees thereof and more while trying to save my childhood home from what is, for all intent and purposes, an illegal foreclosure.This fundraiser is called THE PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN, which is designed to raise money to save my home, located here in Largo, Florida. Obviously a project very near and dear to my heart.TO GIVE YOU SOME BACKGROUND ON HOW ALL THIS CAME TO BE:I grew up in this home, which my mother bought as it was built in 1973. We are the only family that has ever lived in the home. My mother was a widow, my dad having died when I was four. After dad died, my grandma - mom's mom - moved in to help mom take care of me so that mom could work. At the time we moved into the house, I was ten years old.I was 19 when I moved out to marry my first wife. I began working for a comic book store chain in October 1982. I bought the Largo, Florida store on December 1st, 1992, and have continued to run my comic book store ever since, through good times and bad. For four years, I was also a substitute teacher, from 2002 - 2006.Grandma lived with mom in the home after I grew up and moved out. She passed away in the home at age 93 on September 12, 2000. Mom developed lung disease in 2001. By 2003, she was in need of assistance. Mom's lung disease became terminal in 2006. She passed away at home at age 77 on February 6, 2007. I was caregiver to them both in their final years.I was dismissed by the Pinellas County School Board from my substitute teaching position in June 2007 for failing to work as a sub during my mother's final few months, from 2006-2007. After Mom passed, I had to deal with her estate, and I was very emotional. I planned to return to subbing in August of 2007, but the school board refused to hold my position.I moved into the home shortly after mom passed away, in April 2007. The house went through the probate process as part of her estate. By summer of 2007, the house was then put into my name. I had picked up making the mortgage payments when mom died, and continued straight through UNTIL, in May of 2009, I received a letter from the bank -- which was Wachovia at the time -- stating that my mortgage had gone from the $525.00 a month payment to $983.00 due to an escrow shortage. I immediately called the bank, who informed me that the escrow shortage was related to either property taxes or homeowner's insurance.I then began to pursue a plan to refinance the mortgage, but Wachovia's representative stated that they would not allow me to do that, but that I had to do a Loan Modification instead. I didn't know what that was. They told me to write a hardship letter, and told me what to say IN the hardship letter, and to call them back the next day. Meanwhile, they would mail out a Loan Modification package to me. After that call, I spoke to an attorney friend who said yes, Loan Modifications are the thing to do these days. Remember, this was summer of 2009. My accountant said he was doing five of them at the time for clients. This made me feel more secure about moving forward, but I still felt that a refi would have been simpler and safer to do.But Wachovia was the bank, and they held all the cards.When we began the Loan Modification process, I was told that they would be canceling my old account number and assigning my mortgage a NEW account number. When I asked how I would make payments, they said that until the Loan Modification process was complete, I would have no payments. Once it was complete, I would receive a coupon booklet, and have 30 days to make the payments. I would then have to make the payments on time, each month, or would be dropped from the program.I asked if I would be in default. They said no, I would not be in default throughout this process. I asked what happened to the payments I wasn't making. They said all payments, taxes and insurance would be put "on the back end". I asked if there were any penalties, and again, they replied in the negative. There were no fees, fines or penalties because I was doing a Loan Modification.Again, they were the lender. They held all the cards. So I had to believe them, didn't I?I followed through, receiving and returning documents with my accountant's assistance. This process went on for months. Just as I was wondering when the Loan Modification would be approved, in January 2010, I was contacted by Wells Fargo, who had taken over Wachovia. They said that they were canceling my Loan Modification BUT they were putting me in the *new and improved* President's Loan Modification Plan. They made it sound like a sure bet, no problem making it go through, and once again, we had to resubmit all-new forms.Again, I asked them about making payments, and they reiterated: I would have no payments during the Loan Modification process. Likewise, I would not be in default, with all payments, taxes and insurance would be put "on the back end". There would be no fees, fines or penalties because I was doing a Loan Modification.Now it was Wells Fargo holding all the cards, but again, shouldn't I trust them? After all, if all they want is for me to be a current mortgage holder, then this process was the way to go, wasn't it?My accountant assured me, "They have enough houses in foreclosure, Pat. They don't want your home."With his help, I once again threw myself into the process of the Loan Modification machine.Around this time, my friend the attorney, who specializes in family law, said, "Have Wells Fargo fax me a letter stating the terms they've told you. You should have all that in writing."So I called the guy I'd spoken to, who said that he "couldn't fax anything out of the office".I said, "What are you talking about, you can't fax? Then e-mail him a letter."The guy replied, "Oh no, we can't e-mail out of these offices either."I told the attorney what the Wells Fargo rep said, and he replied, "Call him back and have him contact the mortgage department and make SURE they don't put you in foreclosure!""But," I said, "I'm not even in default!" The attorney was adamant, so I did as instructed.The Wells Fargo rep replied, "Oh no, we can't contact that department, we don't have the ability to contact any department outside our own!""What are you talking about, aren't you ALL Wells Fargo?" He said yes, but "the system" wasn't set up to allow them to speak to the other departments.Now, you're all saying what everyone else does at this point. Wasn't I suspicious? Didn't this send up red flags? Sure it did! But Wells Fargo was the new lender, and now it was they who held all the cards! What was I supposed to do, call them all liars?This process went on and on and on -- throughout the entire year of 2010, and through 2011 until September of that year. Throughout that entire time, we would be told that the paperwork had expired, "grown stale", and told to resubmit, resubmit, resubmit some more, which we did ad nauseum. We did everything we were told to do. What else were we SUPPOSED to do?From January 2010 until September 2011, I was traded off from one Home Preservation "Specialist" to another, each one coming across like nothing more than a glorified telemarketer. In September 2011, the third of these "specialists" sent me a letter, denying my Loan Modification -- after over TWO years of being jerked around, claiming that my Profit and Loss statement (for my comic store) was insufficient.By the 28th of September, Wells Fargo had filed a foreclosure against me, and mailed me the paperwork so that it arrived ON my birthday, October 1st, 2011. I spent the day crying.With the help of my attorney friend, I filed a counter against their foreclosure, but was forced to hire an attorney in the beginning of 2012 -- Stamatakis + Thalji + Bonanno -- in Tampa, recommended to my accountant, who passed that information along to me. I gave them a retainer, and they began the process of filing motions to dismiss, among other motions. This point-counterpoint went back and forth without anyone gaining ground for two years. Every so often, we'd hear from them that motions were being filed, but that everything was the same. No change.Here's where things take a BAD TURN, and it all started with -- a wedding!By this point in my life, 2011-2014, I had a girlfriend -- Ashley -- whom I met in the latter days near the end of my first marriage when she began helping out at the comic shop, taking over for the fellow who was moving away, while I was busy taking care of Mom before she died.  After my first wife and I separated again in 2007, Ashley and I became more and more involved, first as friends before becoming near inseparable companions. We have almost everything in common, and our differences in interests are negligible and endearing. My divorce of my first marriage was final December 1st, 2011. Ashley and I became engaged on Christmas Day 2012, almost 13 months later.We envisioned growing older in that house -- she's younger than I am, and would like children of her own -- and spoke of having a family of our own there in my childhood home. I thought of how happy that would have made Mom and Grandma, to bring the joy of a full-on family back to the house. My children are all grown, and I really like the idea of having a second chance to be a dad again. When my first wife and I were married -- very young -- I admit with deep  regret that I was far more self-centered and self-absorbed than I am now. I was a good dad, mind you -- never went out with the boys, or played golf or sports, nor was I abusive in any way -- but I was *a real couch potato*, coming in after work to watch my TV shows, eat dinner, and do my own thing. I regret not spending more time with my kids, other than to help them with homework and read to them sometimes before bedtime. I would love to have a second chance to be a better dad. I can't make up the lost time to my adult children -- I wish I could, because I love them with all my heart -- but I know I'm a better man today than I was when I was younger.Ashley has gone back to college to become an RN, and is currently taking courses. As of December 2014, she has about 18 months remaining before she will have her Associates in Science degree and her RN license.Of course, as couples do, Ashley and I began tossing wedding dates back and forth when we might like to get married. The one date which came up was February 22nd, because that was my Grandma's birthday. It wasn't until I learned that my Dad's parents were also married on February 22nd that I really got that date stuck in my head. It seemed so perfect, to honor my parents and grandparents. I left it up to Ashley, however, because I'd already been married before, and had my big day. She had ideas how we'd proceed with a big ceremony, but felt that we could renew our vows in a big ceremony someday later, when so many things had been sorted out -- not the least of which was the house -- but that we could have a civil ceremony on February 22nd of 2014 because the day fell on a Saturday. It won't fall on a Saturday for six more years, and we didn't want to wait six years for that date to be our wedding anniversary.The entire thing came together in three days, from the day we just spontaneously decided to have our wedding to the date of the wedding. BUT before we did anything, we called the attorneys for the foreclosure defense, because we didn't want ANYTHING to upset the process. The attorney replied, "All this will mean is, when we get into the Loan Modification phase, Ashley will need to provide some proof of income! Otherwise, your getting married won't change a thing!"WRONG.We married as we'd hurriedly planned on February 22nd, filing our license with the Clerk of the Court for Pinellas County, Florida a couple of days later. We were so happy and excited!A couple of months went by. Suddenly, around the end of April, a persistent person kept coming to the house in the mornings, knocking loudly, then leaving and driving away. Well, we're at the comic book store often working late doing paperwork, because that's when it's quiet and Ashley has college classes, as I mentioned earlier. So we're not dressed early in the morning. This went on until the beginning of May, when the person hid his car down the road, and then hid in the neighbor's bushes. Ashley was walking to the car around noon, so we could head to the store. I was just inside the door. The man jumped out, ran across the yard, and served Ashley a set of the foreclosure papers. He began interrogating her, asking her who she was, what business she had at the house and so forth. She had no idea at that moment who he was or what the papers were, so she refused to answer. He ran away as I came out, jumping into his car to speed off.We were then notified in June 2014 that a hearing had been scheduled for August to set a sale date for the house, to force the foreclosure process through to the ultimate conclusion.The attorney told us that we could do one of two things: file for a new Loan Modification, which he could do for $500.00, or file for Bankruptcy Chapter 13 for $1,500.00. He said these would stop the foreclosure process and cancel the hearing. We opted for the Loan Modification process. He then said we'd have to do the Bankruptcy instead, but it was a 1 to 5 year process. I *believed* I understood the idea was to discharge debt while improving my debt-to-income ratio, because I knew that term from having done a refinance with my first wife on our old house back in 2004. So I *thought* I understood what was going on now, and hey -- 1 to 5 years? Ashley would be an RN in less than 2 years, so I thought everything would be fine.WRONG.I was scouring a lot of avenues trying to come up with the $1,500.00 when I wrote a very good friend of mine for advice. In turn, he said, "I'm going to loan you the money to save your house", and God bless him, I still owe him that money (I haven't forgotten), because he DID come through for me!!We contacted the attorney to get him the fifteen hundred, who said, "Well, we'll need another $310.00 for filing fees." We had an additional $200.00, so they agreed to take that. All in all, we gave them $1,700.00 for the Bankruptcy which I *thought* I understood, and clearly did NOT. After they were paid, the attorney was able to stop the foreclosure -- don't cheer yet! It was only temporary -- and call off the hearing with days to spare. THEN he dropped the bombshell, we'd meet with a Bankruptcy trustee within a week, and 30 days later -- by the first of October -- we'd have to start paying TWO THOUSAND DOLLARS A MONTH to stay in the house. If we couldn't agree to that, we wouldn't be able to stay in the house!Why was the monthly amount so high when the Loan Modification -- if it had just gone through originally as planned -- should have reduced the monthly payment from the $983.00 down to around $550.00? Because Wells Fargo has added FEES, PENALTIES, LEGAL FEES, COURT COSTS and MORE to the tune of $50,000.00 on top of the original $82,000.00 mortgage, PLUS tacked on an extra $5,000.00 onto the original mortgage!!Therefore, to get out from under, if I have to pay the entire sum, I'd have to give them $137,000.00!!Obviously, we couldn't agree to do $2,000.00 a month, no matter how much I want to stay in my house. I knew I couldn't come up with that kind of money. The trustee then released the bankruptcy, the foreclosure process began again, and a NEW HEARING is set for December 16, 2014.  Yes, NEXT WEEK!!!!Merry Christmas.We spoke to HUD and looked into the HAMP and HARP programs. After getting a good deal of run around, which left me reduced to tears -- yes, I'm a man, standing in my comic book store, weeping over my boyhood home -- we were told to "approach the lender and start a new Loan Modification".Again, we approached the attorney: "What about the Loan Modification you mentioned?"They replied: "We can do that for $500.00, but the hearing will still go through, and a sale date will be set for your house. Or you can do the Loan Modification yourself."We asked: "Can you take $500.00 from the $1,700.00 we already gave you?"The answer: "No, that money is already spent."So we called Wells Fargo ourselves. The woman we spoke to was nice enough. She said to go to a particular page and download the Loan Modification package. She also mailed us one. She said that the hearing against the house could be canceled and the foreclosure stopped before Thanksgiving. Get the paperwork filled out, send it in, and they would call to do a financial interview. I was excited beyond words. Finally, a chance to breathe!We got the forms, sent them to the accountant, met with him, and he got the forms back to us. This took two weeks of going back and forth -- he also has other clients, I understand that -- and then we called HUD to go over the numbers with THEM before sending the package to Wells Fargo. HUD said it all met the criteria for a successful Loan Modification!Okay, we called Wells Fargo. They said, "Don't e-mail them, FAX them" and then directed us to go to the branch near us and fax the papers from there. We did this on November 21st, 2014. We then expected the call from Wells Fargo.WRONG.There was no call. So WE called. They didn't know who Ashley had spoken to. We said we needed to do the interview. They said someone would call us back. Thanksgiving came and went with no call. Then the first week of December came and went. We called again.The clock is ticking!We also called the attorney. "File a motion to stop the hearing, we've started a Loan Modification! They said the hearing would be canceled if we did that ... we're just waiting for the interview call!" So they filed a motion.But the hearing *wasn't* canceled. So yesterday, we called Wells Fargo AGAIN. Wells Fargo said, "Have your attorney call OUR attorney."There was still no word by this afternoon.Today, December 10th, with six days til doomsday, I had the bright idea to speak with the attorney, Chris Young, with whom I've filed for disability due to health issues largely stemming from an automobile accident in 2010, plus serious  eyesight issues. To digress a moment: I went blind in my right eye in the summer of 2001, and suffered a retinal detachment in my sighted left eye in the summer of 2011, and almost went blind then.So today, I thought -- incorrectly -- that the disability attorney might ALSO be able to file a motion to cancel the hearing against my house, as I am diligently working toward that goal while also seeking a new Loan Modification. Perhaps if both attorneys file? He replied no. Apparently, HE was told by the foreclosure attorney that the hearing will not be canceled. Wells Fargo would rather just foreclose on the house.So much for the statement, "They don't want your house, Pat".They must think there is buried treasure there.We called Wells Fargo again, this afternoon, to demand we get this interview process done. They said we have to FAX THE PAPERWORK AGAIN tomorrow. Can you believe it?? The guy said he can't read the typed and printed responses to their own forms!!SO TOMORROW, with all the paperwork filed -- allegedly -- the Loan Modification process will start again!! BUT the hearing will NOT be canceled. We should go to the Judge next Tuesday, we were told, and tell the Court that we have started a Loan Modification with Wells Fargo!!!IS THIS A JOKE?Am I supposed to believe ANYTHING I am told now?❖ ❖ ❖WHAT ABOUT THAT FUNDRAISER I STARTED TALKING ABOUT?So what is this fundraiser about?Saving the house.What are the perks?Well, I own a comic book store. Maybe we can work out a deal on some comics.As detailed elsewhere ... this Indiegogo format is a whole new world to me, so forgive me if this seems like a repeat:Or maybe you'd like a copy of one of the sketches I am doing for PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN, the project which will detail *the entire process* that I have endured, from start to -- hopefully -- *blessed* finish, with your help. Donate $50.00 for one sketch or cartoon.PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN will be a full-out telling of the facts you've read above, with sketches, illustrations, sarcastic "satirical" cartoons, and more. I intend to publish the book through Amazon's CreateSpace and Kindle Direct Publishing features. Those who donate $100.00 will get a free print copy.The more you contribute, the more you'll get. As I indicated, there will be sketches and cartoons.  Four illustrations -- two sketches, two satirical cartoons -- will be printed on card stock and also made available.  Donate $250.00 for all four pieces of art and a copy of the book.Finally, I intend to do three paintings, the designs of which have long been decided on. Each painting is part of a larger theme. The paintings, when done, will be auctioned off on eBay as a set. The theme is PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN, who will be represented in the paintings as a regular person losing his home and family, only to end up homeless. The paintings speak to what is happening, like a plague, in America today.For those who donate $500.00, you'll get a DVD video of me painting the three paintings, PLUS a free copy of the book, PLUS all four sketches.–  OR – (This part WASN'T mentioned anywhere else)If you don't have a lot of money, would you like to DONATE to preserve the good and decent home built by my mother, Rita Potter? Mom worked as a Pediatric Psych Nurse (an RN and CN 4) at Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Florida for over two decades, helping THOUSANDS of young people overcome addictions to drugs as well as deal with psychological disorders, abusive environments, and many distressing issues.I'm just a comic book store owner. I'm not changing the world. While I would still like to finish my degree in education, survival is the name of the game today. Ashley, on the other hand, has a bright future ahead of her as an RN. Her dream is to work as a Pediatric floor nurse. Helping us save the house is ALSO helping to secure a solid home environment to help Ashley focus on her courses, so that she is not faced with the prospect of being displaced from the home she has come to love so much.PLEASE HELP US save our home.It could be as simple as 400,000 people each donating 25 cents per person.A simple quarter of a dollar could make a difference if enough people can donate to this worthy cause.What's in it for you?How many times have the banks, the mortgage companies, and other large organizations spewed their venom and bile onto your lives?This is YOUR chance to stand up to them!  YOU can make a difference by not letting them win!!Throughout this entire process, I've been told one bald-faced lie after another, and now they want me to swallow the lie that going through the hearing won't result in the foreclosure and sale of my house? That I'll be allowed to complete a Loan Modification?While I had considered doing this fundraiser many times in the past six months, I did not sit down to write any of this until after Wells Fargo fed us that line of malarkey!!Yes, tomorrow, we WILL follow through and submit the paperwork. Again.Yes, tomorrow, we WILL call Wells Fargo YET AGAIN to try to see if the foreclosure process can be stopped.Yes, tomorrow, we WILL once more attempt to have the hearing against our home stopped.I DO intend to file a DIRECT request with the Judge. I will go to the Courthouse in Clearwater and file it before I ever set foot in the door of the store. AND I will make sure I have a stamped confirmation that they received it.Yes, I will go through the motions.But in the end, I BELIEVE IT'S PEOPLE LIKE YOU who will make the difference!!WE all represent THE  COMMON MAN, and by that I mean "Mankind", meaning ALL GENDERS, as well as sexual orientations, cultures, ethnicity, and religions.The government consisting of agencies such as HUD and the like, the banks like Wells Fargo and Bank of America, and institutions who say that they will help people like me and you are not in it to help people like you and me, they're in it to help THEMSELVES.But we can pull together as a people, and not just a nation here in the United States, but as a world of people everywhere. We have to help one another when we can, while we can.Today, Ashley and I need your help.Please donate to THE PLIGHT OF THE COMMON MAN fundraiser today.Time is of the essence.Thank you.Patrick PotterLargo, Florida❖ ❖ ❖Risks and ChallengesI've been asked what risks and challenges I face. In fact, the only challenge is time. There is no risk, unless I don't meet the goal and / or the courts decide NOT to stave off the execution by allowing a sale date to be set for my home.BUT, if we meet the goal, I believe we can seriously pay off the home! In that case, I have nothing negatively impacting me to prevent me from completing the project, because what banks like Wells Fargo has done is despicable, and I am passionate to want to speak out against the kind of dirty tricks they have used to, for all intents and purposes "steal" people's homes from under them!I am an extremely multi-talented individual. I am an outstanding writer, an excellent cartoonist and artist, and I am sarcastic and angry enough to follow through and pull off EXACTLY what I am promising you here!My wife is a wonderful person who can keep the store going if I need to take time away from the shop to stay home and focus on the task, so I know I can meet the deadline I have set for myself.

UPDATE: Cristen was able to independently secure the funds needed for the conference before our campaign ended!  Thank you SO MUCH to everyone who donated and made her trip possible!  From Cristen on November 7, 2013:
https://www.facebook.com/cristen.pascucci/posts/10201509397910409

*********

Cristen has been partnering with Human Rights in Childbirth through her work as the Vice President of ImprovingBirth.org to build a legal advocacy network for mothers in the U.S.  Cristen has also been the woman behind the ImprovingBirth.org "hotline" for the past year.  

She has been asked to attend the Human Rights in Childbirth Conference in Blankenberge, Belgium on November 4, 2013 to lead a roundtable about how women and lawyers can partner for change.  This is a tremendous opportunity for Cristen, for ImprovingBirth.org, and for American mothers.  Cristen is a talented, passionate, and intelligent woman and an excellent candidate to represent American mothers.  Additionally, filmmakers from the Freedom for Birth documentary have also asked to film Cristen for the "sequel" to Freedom for Birth while she is there. 

Cristen left her corporate job 2 years ago and has since been working (more than full time) as a volunteer for ImprovingBirth.org.  Due this personal sacrifice on behalf of others Cristen needs help getting to Belgium.  Like many women, she struggles to ask publicly for this type of financial support.  Therefore, I'm taking it upon myself to ask on her behalf.

story:
Áxwet  To Share Food with Someone

 

Íwest Kú:kw  To show something to somebody, to cook

By Warren King George, Muckleshoot and Upper Skagit Tribe And Elizabeth M. Swanaset

Member of the Nooksack Indian Tribe and Cowichan Nation

 

Traditionally, families gathered many types of foods throughout the year and preserved the food in many different ways.  Today, some of those techiniques still exist and with today's technology, it has become easier.  This idea that we have, of creating a cookbook, will benefit our communities in many ways.  Sharing good food with another person does not only satisfy ones hunger, but it also heals what is with in, by providing a warmth to ones spirit.  When food is prepared with love and labor, it brings to the dish another ingredient that you cannot purchase in a grocery store.  We want to encompass this and bring it to many others. We love cooking and gathering foods.

With this funding, Warren King George and I will be able to continue to create and document the different ingrediants that we find and gather around the Salish Sea areas.  How it was prepared traditionally and how it can be done in today's world.  We have many documented now and it is posted on our facebook page, Salish Sea Traditional foods.  Now we just intend to pull it all together and makea and have the book published.

We will conduct interviews with Elders who have been known to be cooks in their day of how traditional foods were gathered and prepared.  What they remember as a child eating and how it was served.  And then we will contrast that with today's ways of using the same foods.  

Contibuters will be gifted with a cook book upon completion!

Thank you :)

story:
Summary

I have been teaching formally for 8 years, and am currently teaching 4th grade. I have been writing poetry for a lot longer than that, having hosted open mics, slams, and performed and led workshops in schools and theaters across the country. 

I am honored to do what I do. I believe that teaching is one of the most noble and important professions that exists. This book is inspired by the experiences I've had in the realm of education, the people I've encountered, heard or learned about, and the challenges (new and familiar) that we struggle through, in order to change lives.

'Who Wants To Be a Teacher?' is a collection of poems (and a few anecdotes) that will hopefully open some minds to the true struggles and value of the future shapers who's work can not be measured in the hours spent inside of a school building. 

The purpose of this project is to publish this collection of poems, in both print, and digital audio. The $2,500 will cover the printing of the first batch of books, the ISBN and copyright registration fees, the recording/distribution costs for the audio tracks, and promotional materials for the project. 

The Impact

Last year, I had a successfully funded campaign to publish two children's books. Since then, I have been bringing my books to festivals, conventions, establishing an online presence, and have been using them in school with my students. I have also sold books to school districts, and have developed educational guides for each of the books, for teachers.

story_txt:
Summary
I have been teaching formally for 8 years, and am currently teaching 4th grade. I have been writing poetry for a lot longer than that, having hosted open mics, slams, and performed and led workshops in schools and theaters across the country. 
I am honored to do what I do. I believe that teaching is one of the most noble and important professions that exists. This book is inspired by the experiences I've had in the realm of education, the people I've encountered, heard or learned about, and the challenges (new and familiar) that we struggle through, in order to change lives.
'Who Wants To Be a Teacher?' is a collection of poems (and a few anecdotes) that will hopefully open some minds to the true struggles and value of the future shapers who's work can not be measured in the hours spent inside of a school building. 
The purpose of this project is to publish this collection of poems, in both print, and digital audio. The $2,500 will cover the printing of the first batch of books, the ISBN and copyright registration fees, the recording/distribution costs for the audio tracks, and promotional materials for the project. 


The Impact
Last year, I had a successfully funded campaign to publish two children's books. Since then, I have been bringing my books to festivals, conventions, establishing an online presence, and have been using them in school with my students. I have also sold books to school districts, and have developed educational guides for each of the books, for teachers.  
I hope that this book will help to open some eyes as to what it's really like for teachers inside and out of the classroom, and inspire some to either press on, or throw support behind those of us who do so everyday. I hope that this book finds its way into the hands of teachers, parents, administrators, lawmakers, and anyone else who has ever had a teacher.

story:
Big Thank You for helping us to hire our editor! We have more 5 days...and still need your help to publish Dance Me Home this Fall.  

 


Mid-Campaign Update!


Dance Me Home, A Moving Journey 

Dance Me Home is a story about what it is like to leave one’s comfort zone and explore a life long passion.

For me that meant leaving a successful high tech career to explore, experience and support eight dances in cultures around the world. 

Journey with me to the source of these dances and into the beauty and love of Indian temple dances, ancient Hawaiian hula, Brazilian Orixa movement, Argentine Tango,  Spanish Flamenco, Bulgarian Folk Dance, Turkish Whirling dervishes, and traditional Native American Lakota Sundance.

You will meet amazing people and discover how we may all connect through dance back to ourselves, to each other and to something greater.  

With each individual contribution, you will be helping to hire my editor, a seasoned professional who will help me to complete the final steps to finish the first edition of Dance Me Home!  This will also help with the design and layout of the book which includes several pictures of each dance, and first printed copies. 

My professional experience in marketing and business development give me a strong foundation to help promote Dance Me Home once it is completed.

My plan is for you to have Dance Me Home in your hands, or on your computer, by September 2014.

Bringing the Dances to Life 

I believe much of what I experienced and enjoyed along this journey was a gift and I would like to share the gift of these beautiful, joyful, peaceful, healing dances with you and others. Completing and publishing Dance Me Home allows me to do that.  It is time.

And you can help me do it!  Whether you choose to help spread the word, or you decide to contribute and find a Perk that moves you - it all makes a difference. Every contribution and donation is greatly appreciated. 

To raise the $13,000 to complete this book, we have designed perks that help you step into an experience of Dance Me Home and encourage you to have your own journey. Whether you choose a copy of the book, photos, a movement workshop, an evening with a Lakota medicine man or join me on a dance adventure - we hope you enjoy being part of our Moving Journey! 

My hope is that reading Dance Me Home will inspire you as much as being there and taking part inspired me. I hope that you enjoy intimate access and my insights into these dances.  I also hope you may receive the many gifts they offer. I  believe you will find there is good medicine and deep meaning in these stories.

On this journey, I was fortunate to discover many kind, passionate, generous, genuine, loving, and devoted people that opened and shared their lives and their dance of life with me. 

In that spirit, I sincerely thank you for taking part in fulfilling my journey, and bringing it to life in print.  

As we go along, I will share updates, excerpts, and photos.

Big Thank You 

Dancing is in our hearts and has been since the beginning of time.  It reconnects us and brings us together.   We are in a time where rediscovering ways to connect and come back together are greatly needed. 

Often people ask me if I am a professional dancer. I am not, nor did I have formal training in dance prior to embarking on my journey. Dance is a passion. I respect its power to connect, am moved by its beauty and delighted by its many forms.  

I entered into an experience of each of these dances as a supporter, witness and then often as a participant.   I acknowledge and thank the ancestors, teachers, guides, spirits, and people that contributed to my experiences and journey. 

Each dance could command its own book and a lifetime to truly master. I am grateful for the experiences and the gifts given to me through them and the freedom and joy to share with you. 

Thank you for your time, interest and support!  

Please share Dance Me Home and this Campaign with others who may find something here that inspires or moves them.  Indiegogo has sharing tools that help make it easy.

With love and gratitude, 

Lynn Wallace

story:
Help us raise £5,000 towards the cost of bus adverts in Dundee ahead of the referendum.

With your help we intend to raise £5,000 towards the cost of placing adverts on dozens of buses across Dundee in the weeks ahead of the independence referendum.

Don't wake up on the 19th of September feeling that you should have done more.

Help us secure a Yes vote - please donate what you can.

What You Will Receive As Thanks for Donating

You can donate as much or as little as you like, but if you donate any of these set amounts you will receive a limited edition perk:

  • For a £5 donation you will receive a Yes lapel badge (colour choice, subject to availability).
  • For a £10 donation you will receive a badge, PLUS a Yes pen.
  • For a £20 donation you will receive all of the above, PLUS a Yes car sticker.
  • For a £50 donation you will receive all of the above, PLUS a Yes Scotland mug.
  • For a £120 donation you will receive all of the above, PLUS a custom-made Yes Dundee t-shirt with your name on the back crediting you as a sponsor of a single-decker bus.
  • For a £200 donation you will receive all of the £50 perks, PLUS a custom-made Yes Dundee t-shirt with your name on the back crediting you as a sponsor of a double-decker bus.
  • For a £500 donation you will receive all of the £50 perks, PLUS an invitation to the launch of the buses and a custom-made t-shirt crediting you as being a super-sponsor.

What We Need

Here is what your contributions taken together will help to buy:

  • £120 will pay for an advert along the outside of a single-decker bus.
  • £200 will pay for a HUGE advert on the side of a double-decker bus.

The more money that we can raise, the more buses that we can pay for.

The Impact: Securing a Yes vote

Our adverts will be placed on buses at the most crucial time, in the weeks leading up to the independence referendum on 18th September. Our various customised adverts will:

Set out the benefits of a Yes vote.

Spell out the damaging consequences of a No vote.

Help us to secure a Yes vote in Dundee and across Scotland.

Please share!

Please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter to help us reach our fundraising goal.

The legal stuff:

"In compliance with political funding laws (which we must adhere to), if you donate more than £500, your details have to be checked to ensure you are on the electoral register in Scotland. If you donate more than £7,500 in the course of a calendar year, your name and the amount of the donation will be registered with the Electoral Commission for publication on their public register of donations. The money you use to make a donation must be from your own funds. You must not pass on money from a third party. It is an offence not to reveal the true source of a donation."

story:
After spending the last eight years writing about where to find $5,000 hamburgers and handbags in Las Vegas for some of the top entertainment and luxury lifestyle magazines in the city, I decided it was time to trade excess for inspiration. So, I packed up my Louboutins and returned to my hometown of Sioux Falls, S.D. to  pursue my dream of writing books that promote a positive message.

My first book, Storm of Awakening, an adult personal-growth book about how to use your spiritual gifts to awaken your passions and find your purpose, helped me realize my passion for writing children's rhyming books.

Lynzee, the Lovable Goat is a precocious, strong-willed goat, who believes she can do anything human "kids" can do. In the first book of the series, Ballerina Dreams, Lynzee dreams of becoming a prima ballerina. Even though she doesn't look like the other pretty, petite ballerinas, she quickly discovers it's our differences that make us unique and special. 

["Ballerina Dreams" excerpt: So what if I am not like the others … the beauty in any rainbow, you will discover, lies in all the different shapes and colors.]
Lynzee is a sweet children's rhyming picture book that encourages children to believe in their dreams no matter how big or impossible they may seem. Even as adults, we should never give up on our dreams. … There is a Lynzee in each of us--we all have dreams--but it's usually our insecurities and self-doubt that keep us from going after them. 

Please help me realize my dream of sharing the story of Lynzee, the Lovable Goat to children and adults alike.


What We Need 

I am looking to raise $15,000 to cover self-publishing costs, which include a professional illustrator, layout, graphic design, printing, marketing and the purchase of 200 books to be sent to select children's hospitals, schools, churches and charities.

Any funds raised beyond the $15,000 goal will go towards the second book in the series, Lynzee and the Magical Shoes.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out about Lynzee, by sharing this profile using the Indiegogo share tools. Also, if you are a charity or know of a children's charity that would be interested in receiving Ballerina Dreams for their library, please send me an email. 

Lynzee loves meeting new friends!  Like us on Facebook.

Thank you for taking time to read about the Lynzee project and for your consideration.

story:
UPDATE:

We met our goal!!

WOW! We are beyond overjoyed and our gratitude is deeper than any words could express.

YOU MADE IT HAPPEN!

We’ve SURPASSED our goal of raising $13,000 towards published the book by $3,128!

We now have $16,128 to make “Green Card YOUTH Voices: Immigration Stories from an American High School” the best it can be.

We couldn’t be more humbled by your generosity and support. You have shown us that your words of support have been met with actions of financial contributions.

The students are ecstatic, our staff and board members are celebrating. We CAN make a difference and we ARE. Together we have shown these students that THEY MATTER, that THEIR STORIES ARE VALUABLE, and that THEIR CONTRIBUTIONS ARE PRICELESS.

We could not have done it without you.

Again, THANK YOU.

With the most heartfelt gratitude,

The Green Card Voices team (Tea Rozman Clark, Rachel Mueller, Jose Guzman, Zoe Nardone), and the students and teachers from Wellstone International High School


About this Project:

Green Card YOUTH Voices: Immigration Stories from an American High School is a collection of 30 personal essays from young, new Americans. To be published in May 2016, this is the first in a series of books featuring immigrant stories recorded by Green Card Voices.

In September 2015, Green Card Voices was honored to film the stories of 30 students from Wellstone International High School in Minneapolis, Minnesota. These courageous youth, coming from 13 countries, joined us in the studio for three days and candidly shared stories of family, school, change, and dreams. 

Now for the first time, these incredible accounts will be featured on our website AND in a book! The students are working hard to develop their recorded narratives into written content, and are ready to become published authors.

However, we need your help!



Why a book?

The student authors featured in Green Card YOUTH Voices: Immigration Stories from an American High School have amazing stories to tell. After recording their narratives in September, we knew that this was bigger than just a recording. We wanted to go a step further and bring their stories to an even wider audience with a powerful book and video multimedia package.

Students at the Wellstone International High School will never sit in class next to an American-born student. We feel there is a need for materials that can create bridges between these youth. Green Card YOUTH Voices: Immigration Stories from an American High School will serve as a strong educational resource that individuals and classrooms in Minnesota and beyond can use to learn about their neighbors.

The LIMITED EDITION book will include:

  • 30 narratives written by the students

  • Full page, color portraits of each student*

  • A QR code that links to the student's video interview on the GCV website

  • A short bio of each student

  • A study guide and glossary of terms

*full color in limited edition only

Revenue earned through the sales of the books will be used to fund the GCV's Youth Empowerment Program and contribute to the long-term sustainability of Educational Programs at Green Card Voices.

Why now?

This past year has seen some of the most negative immigrant rhetoric to date. 

In the current climate, it is more important than ever to use individual accounts to highlight the lives lived and contributions made to our nation. At Green Card Voices, we believe stories are a critical part of this movement.


Why you?

We can’t make this book without your support.

The youth of America truly are the future of America— by helping fund this project, you are joining us in empowering a generation that will work to build a nation where all voices are heard and valued.


What We Need

Green Card Voices is a small 501(c)3 non-profit with a limited budget. Funds raised in this campaign will go towards:

  • Printing 1,000 limited edition, full-color books 

  • Copy editing 

  • Video Editor/Book Designer 

  • Managing Editor

  • Marketing 

Our first priorities are the printing costs and copy editing. These costs are non-negotiable and 100% necessary to make the book happen. If we don't reach our goal, we will raise the funds for staff time and marketing through other avenues. 


About Green Card Voices:

Launched in 2013, Green Card Voices utilizes digital storytelling to share personal narratives of America’s immigrants, fostering tolerance and establishing a better understanding between immigrant and non-immigrant populations.

Using web-based video storytelling, touring exhibits, and now launching a brand new book series, Green Card Voices aims to help people see the ‘wave of immigrants’ as individuals, with interesting stories of family, hard work, and cultural diversity. Our dynamic, multimedia platform is designed to empower individuals, community groups, and educational institutions alike.

As participants in a movement calling for increased representation of real immigrant stories in the media, we provide immigrants with a platform to tell their own stories, in exactly the ways they want them to be heard.


We really can’t do this without you!

Every dollar counts, so we appreciate whatever contribution you are able to make! If you can’t donate financially, there are many other ways to get involved.

We’d love to hear from you, so go ahead and leave us a comment if you like what we’re doing. Most importantly, please share this campaign with your friends, families, coworkers, and social media networks! You can find us on Facebook and Twitter to stay updated with the campaign and other events. And be sure to check back here over the next 40 days— we’ll be posting updates every step of the way.
